qas.question: What do most elderly people worry about?
Is an eldery person with alzheimers having the same problem as a similar aged person experiencing memory loss?
Which part of the brain is associated with the memory loss an elderly person suffers?
Which memory is an elderly person helping by using appointment books?
What is one of key concerns of younger adults?
What is not one of the hallmark symptoms of Alzheimer's disease?

plausible_answers.text: However, memory loss is qualitatively different in normal aging from the kind of memory loss associated with a diagnosis of Alzheimer's

qas.question: What did Alzheimer & Price state in 2005?

plausible_answers.text: deficits on tasks that involve knowing the temporal order in which they learned information

qas.question: Older adults can manage their problems with prospective memory by not using what?

context: One of the key concerns of older adults is <b4_0>the experience of <a0_0><b5_0>memory loss<b5_0/><b4_0/>,<a0_0/> especially as it is one of the hallmark symptoms of Alzheimer's disease. <b6_0>However, <a1_0>memory loss is qualitatively different<a1_0/> in normal aging from the kind of memory loss associated with a diagnosis of Alzheimer's<b6_0/> (Budson & Price, 2005). Research has revealed that individuals’ performance on memory tasks that rely on <a2_0>frontal regions<a2_0/> declines with age. Older adults tend to exhibit <b7_0>deficits on tasks that involve knowing the temporal order in which they learned information<b7_0/>; source memory tasks that require them to remember the specific circumstances or context in which they learned information; and prospective memory tasks that involve remembering to perform an act at a future time. Older adults can manage their problems with <a3_0>prospective memory<a3_0/> by using <b8_0>appointment books<b8_0/>, for example.
